content.title: Temperature & Humidity Management
content.content: Gargoyle geckos are temperate tropical species from New Caledonia requiring moderate temperatures (82-85F basking, 70-75F cool) and high humidity (60-80%). This guide covers thermal gradient creation, heating equipment, misting protocols, and troubleshooting environmental issues.

Temperature Limits: Gargoyle geckos tolerate cooler temperatures better than excessive heat. NEVER exceed 88F - prolonged exposure above 85F causes stress, dehydration, and respiratory issues. Temperatures below 65F slow metabolism and digestion. Maintain 82-85F basking maximum with 70-75F cool zone at all times.
Gargoyle geckos need a vertical thermal gradient due to arboreal nature - warmest at top (basking), coolest at bottom (ground level).

rows: 12-15 inches height in center of enclosure
Substrate level away from heat source
Turn off heat source - ambient room temp
Coldest area of enclosure at night

content.content: Vertical Gradient Key: Unlike terrestrial reptiles with horizontal gradients (hot side  cool side), gargoyle geckos need VERTICAL gradients. Top of enclosure = warmest (82-85F), bottom = coolest (70-75F). This allows gecko to climb up for warmth or down to cool - mimics natural tree canopy behavior.

No light emission, long lifespan (2-3 years)

content.text: Heating Setup & Placement:

items: Position: Mount heat source on screen top or suspended above top - creates warmest zone at top third of enclosure
Basking Distance: Heat bulb should be 6-10 inches above highest basking branch. Closer = hotter spot
Dimmer vs Thermostat: 40w bulb with dimmer works for most setups ($15-20). Thermostat required for CHE/DHP for safety ($30-50)
Guard/Dome: Always use ceramic dome fixture rated for bulb wattage. Metal screen cages prevent direct contact burns
Multiple Branches: Provide branches at various heights (6", 12", 18") so gecko can choose preferred temperature
Night Heat: Turn OFF heat source at night in most climates. Only use nighttime heat if room drops below 65F

content.content: Thermostat Safety: Ceramic Heat Emitters and Deep Heat Projectors reach surface temps of 240-400F and MUST use thermostats to prevent fires and overheating. Standard incandescent bulbs (40-60w) can use dimmer switches OR thermostats. NEVER use red/blue colored bulbs - disrupt circadian rhythm. Use white daylight bulbs only.

content.text: Essential Tools:

items: Infrared Temperature Gun (Most Important): $15-25. Measures surface temperature instantly. Aim at basking branch, mid-level branch, substrate. Take readings 3-4x daily first week
Digital Thermometer/Hygrometer Combo: $10-15. Displays ambient air temp and humidity. Place probe at mid-level (12-15 inches height)
DO NOT Use: Stick-on dial thermometers (wildly inaccurate 10F), analog hygrometers (lag 30+ minutes), or colored zone thermometers

content.text: Measurement Protocol:

items: Measure basking spot surface temp (top branch) with infrared gun - should read 82-85F when heat source on
Measure mid-level branch (feeding area) - target 76-80F
Measure substrate/ground level - target 70-75F
Check ambient air temp at mid-level with digital thermometer - should match infrared mid-level reading within 2-3F
Monitor for 7-10 days during initial setup, adjusting bulb wattage/height until consistent gradient achieved
After stable gradient established: Check temps 2-3x weekly, daily during seasonal weather changes

content.content: Temperature Troubleshooting: If entire enclosure too hot (>85F at basking): Lower bulb wattage (60w  40w) or raise fixture height. If entire enclosure too cool (<75F mid-level): Increase bulb wattage (40w  60w) or lower fixture. If gradient insufficient (all zones same temp): Add ventilation or reposition branches vertically.

Gargoyle geckos require 60-80% humidity average with nightly peaks to 85-90% after misting. Humidity too low causes dehydration and stuck shed; too high (>85% constantly) causes respiratory infections.

rows: Heavy misting - 30-40 sprays covering all surfaces
Natural evaporation from morning mist + substrate moisture
Moderate humidity, allows enclosure to dry partially
Second misting session - 30-40 sprays before lights out
Residual moisture from evening mist + closed room ventilation
Natural nighttime humidity, prevents respiratory issues from constant saturation
Combination of 2x daily misting + moisture-retentive substrate
Overall target - gecko should never experience <50% or >90% for extended periods

content.text: Signs of Incorrect Humidity:

items: Too Low (<50% consistently): Wrinkled/dull skin, sunken eyes, stuck shed (especially on toes/tail tip), lethargy, dehydration
Too High (>90% constantly): Respiratory infection (wheezing, open-mouth breathing, mucus), excessive mold growth, bacterial skin infections, lethargy
Ideal Signs: Clear bright eyes, smooth skin, complete sheds, active behavior, regular feeding

content.text: Manual Misting (Budget Option):

items: Equipment: Pump pressure sprayer ($15-25) - NOT trigger spray bottles (inconsistent, hand fatigue). Brands: Chapin, Vivosun, Hudson
Water Type: Dechlorinated tap water preferred (minerals beneficial) OR filtered water. Room temperature (70-75F)
Morning Session (7-9 AM): 30-40 sprays covering glass walls, branches, foliage. Create visible water droplets on all surfaces
Evening Session (6-9 PM): 30-40 sprays again - same coverage. Time with feeding (offer CGD after misting)
Technique: Mist side walls and décor - let water run down naturally. Avoid spraying gecko directly (stresses them)
Duration: Each session 2-3 minutes total. Enclosure should look "rainforest wet" with droplets everywhere

content.text: Automatic Misting Systems (Advanced):

items: Entry Level: Exo Terra Monsoon ($70-90) - programmable timer, 1L reservoir, covers 1-2 enclosures
Mid-Range: MistKing Starter ($150-180) - superior pump quality, expandable, quieter operation
Premium: Cli-Mist or HerpMist ($200-300) - commercial quality, multiple enclosures, precise control
Programming: Set for 60-90 seconds misting at 8 AM and 7 PM daily
Maintenance: Clean nozzles monthly with vinegar (prevents mineral buildup), replace reservoir water weekly

content.content: Misting System Note: Automatic misters are convenience upgrades, NOT requirements. Manual misting with pressure sprayer works perfectly for 1-3 enclosures. Only invest in automatic systems if maintaining 4+ enclosures or travel frequently. Poor-quality systems ($30-50) fail within months - invest in quality or stick with manual.

content.text: Summer Adjustments (High Ambient Temps):

items: If room temperature exceeds 78-80F, TURN OFF heat source during hottest hours (12-4 PM)
Increase ventilation - remove partial screen covers, add small fan in room (not directly on enclosure)
Maintain misting schedule - may need to increase to 3x daily if humidity drops below 60%
Monitor basking spot - should never exceed 85F even with heat source off
If room consistently above 82F: Use room air conditioning or relocate enclosure to cooler area

content.text: Winter Adjustments (Low Ambient Temps):

items: If room temperature drops below 70F during day, increase heat source wattage (40w  60w) or add second fixture
If nighttime temps drop below 65F, add low-wattage Ceramic Heat Emitter (25-40w) on thermostat set to 68F
Winter air drier - increase misting duration by 30-50% (45-60 sprays per session) OR add fogger for humidity boost
Consider room humidifier (40-50% room humidity helps enclosure maintain 60-80%)
Cover 25-50% of screen top with acrylic sheet or plastic wrap to retain heat and humidity (ensure ventilation remains)

content.text: Year-Round Monitoring:

items: Re-check temperature gradients when outdoor seasons change (spring, summer, fall, winter)
Adjust heating and misting schedules proactively before gecko shows stress signs
Keep digital thermometer/hygrometer visible for quick daily checks
Log temps weekly in notebook or phone app to track patterns and catch issues early
Expect to adjust equipment 2-4 times per year as ambient conditions change

content.content: Environmental Success Summary: Maintain 82-85F basking (top third), 76-80F mid-level, 70-75F cool zone (bottom). Drop to 65-72F at night. Keep humidity 60-80% average via 2x daily misting. Measure temps with infrared gun weekly. Adjust equipment seasonally. Gargoyle geckos tolerate cooler temps better than heat - err on cooler side if uncertain.
